title: Hookes law-magnitude and direction of spring force

content.question: A block is attached to one end of a horizontal ideal spring whose other end is attached to a wall. The spring is initially unstretched and its right end is at position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The block is then pulled until it is at a position <math alttext="x equals positive A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, where the spring exerts a force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> on the block. The spring is then moved to a position <math alttext="x equals negative A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Which of the following correctly indicates the magnitude and direction of the force the spring exerts on the block in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> to the left
<math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> to the right
<math alttext="2 F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>F</mi></math> to the left
<math alttext="2 F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>F</mi></math> to the right

content.answer: <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> to the right
